text:
Don’t compare police troubles with persecuted Jews, Israeli consulate urges 
Diplomatic mission in Hong Kong expresses regret over speaker addressing mass gathering of officers PUBLISHED : Thursday, 23 February, 2017, 5:57pm UPDATED : Thursday, 23 February, 2017, 6:06pm 33,000 turn out in support of officers jailed over Occupy beating 23 Feb 2017 
The Israeli consulate in Hong Kong has expressed regret that a policeman at a mass gathering on Wednesday in support of colleagues convicted of assaulting a protester likened their tribulations to those of persecuted Jews. 
“Without relating to the trial of the seven police officers, the alleged statement at the rally that made a reference to the persecution of Jews in Nazi Germany is inappropriate and regretful,” the diplomatic mission said in a statement on Thursday. 
Watch: More than 30,000 gather to support jailed policemen 
“We wish no further comparison will be made to the Jewish Holocaust,” it added. 
Wednesday’s gathering in support of seven officers convicted last week was held at the Police Sports and Recreation Club in Mong Kok and drew some 33,000 serving and retired officers and their relatives. We wish no further comparison will be made to the Jewish Holocaust Israeli Consulate General 
Officers took turns taking the stage to address the crowd. One speaker was filmed comparing insults officers had received with the Nazi persecution of Jews during the second world war. 
A video recorded by Apple Daily captured an officer addressing the crowds. “I would say it’s like we’re now in the second world war,” the speaker said. “We are Jews. And we’re facing persecution. We are Jews facing the persecution of the Nazis, aren’t we?” 
The crowd then shouted “yes” in response. 
The mass gathering, organised by the major police associations, followed the convictions last week of seven officers for assaulting Occupy Central activist Ken Tsang Kin-chiu, who was unarmed at the time, during a protest in October 2014. 
Their sentencing sparked an outpouring of condemnation by police officers and segments of the public complaining the city’s courts had been far more lenient with Occupy protesters who had broken the law. 
Watch: Hong Kong policemen found guilty in Occupy activist case 
Retired deputy police commissioner Tony Wong Chi-hung, among those present, said he had attended the event to “support my colleagues”. 
A spokesman for the organisers of Wednesday night’s event could not immediately be reached for comment. 
Meanwhile, pro-establishment lawmaker Priscilla Leung Mei-fun of the Business and Professionals Alliance said she planned to introduce laws to criminalise insulting police officers. 
“Amending the existing laws to protect the police from being severely insulted when they are exercising their duty is also meant to protect the public,” she said. 
Insiders worry as anger at officers’ jailing for Ken Tsang beating spreads through Hong Kong police 
Her group has raised HK$5 million in support of the seven officers’ families. 
Alliance vice-chairman and lawmaker Jeffrey Lam Kin-Fung said donations had been pouring in since the idea was circulated among the group’s members and supporters. 
Meanwhile, Democratic Party lawmaker Lam Cheuk-ting warned that having a “contempt of cop” law would only “worsen the relationship between the police force and the general public”.
